procedure: Arthroscopic anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction, right knee
Arthroscopic partial medial meniscectomy, right knee
extraction_data.summary: 28-year-old male recreational basketball player with pivot injury and persistent instability despite bracing and therapy. Patient underwent arthroscopic ACL reconstruction and partial medial meniscectomy of the right knee. Diagnostic arthroscopy confirmed ACL insufficiency and peripheral medial meniscus tear, with torn meniscal fragments trimmed to a stable rim and ACL graft secured with interference screws.

documentation: Function-limiting pain for at least six (6) months in duration (Evidence: pg no: 4, L156-L157)
Abnormal shoulder physical examination findings compared to non-involved side including functionally limited range of motion or measurable loss in strength (Evidence: pg no: 4, L158-L161)
Positive Neer Impingement Test or Hawkins-Kennedy Impingement Test (Evidence: pg no: 4, L162)
Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration (Evidence: pg no: 4, L163-L164)
Advanced diagnostic imaging study (e.g., MRI, CT) is inconclusive for internal derangement/pathology (Evidence: pg no: 4, L165)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 4, L166-L168)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 5, L171-L172)
In-office diagnostic arthroscopy (e.g., Mi-Eye™, VisionScope®) - considered experimental, investigational, or unproven (Evidence: pg no: 5, L175-L176)

documentation: Function-limiting pain (Evidence: pg no: 10, L410-L412)

Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration, except for discrete traumatic event resulting in acute proximal biceps tendon rupture (Evidence: pg no: 10, L413-L416)

Advanced diagnostic imaging study (e.g., MRI, CT) demonstrates labral tear/biceps tendon pathology (e.g., SLAP, Bankart, full-thickness subscapularis tear) and correlates with symptoms and physical exam findings (Evidence: pg no: 10, L417-L420)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain, cervical radiculopathy, and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L421-L423)
Minimally limited or full shoulder range of motion (Evidence: pg no: 10, L426)

ONE OR MORE positive physical exam findings including O'Brien's Test, Biceps Load Test, Clunk Test, Anterior Slide Test, Compression Rotation Test, Speed's Test, Upper cut test, Popeye sign, Yergason's test, Proximal biceps (groove) tenderness (Evidence: pg no: 10, L427-L437)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 10, L439-L440)

codes.description: Tenodesis of long tendon of biceps (Evidence: pg no: 13, L545)
Resection or transplantation of long tendon of biceps (Evidence: pg no: 13, L546)
Arthroscopy, shoulder, surgical; biceps tenodesis (Evidence: pg no: 14, L586)

full_source.notes: Conservative management exception for acute proximal biceps tendon rupture (Evidence: pg no: 10, L414-L416)

Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L844-L845)

Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)

names: Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 10, L300)
Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178)
full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. This procedure is typically utilized when there is concomitant rotator cuff disease. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178-L180)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 7, L181-L183)

documentation: Reconstruction after a tumor resection (Evidence: pg no: 10, L302)
Glenohumeral osteoarthritis with irreparable rotator cuff tear (Evidence: pg no: 10, L303)
Glenoid bone stock inadequate to support a glenoid prosthesis (Evidence: pg no: 10, L304)
Failed hemiarthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 10, L305)
Failed total shoulder arthroplasty with non-repairable rotator cuff (Evidence: pg no: 10, L306)
Shoulder fracture that is not repairable or cannot be reconstructed with other techniques (Evidence: pg no: 10, L307)
Deficient rotator cuff with limited ability to actively flex the upper extremity to 90 degrees against gravity (Evidence: pg no: 10, L310-L311)

full_source.notes: Considered medically necessary for ANY of the listed indications when associated with pain and functional impairment. (Evidence: pg no: 10, L301)

full_source.description: Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also referred to as total hip replacement (THR), involves removal of the femoral head and acetabulum and placement of a prosthesis anchored to the bone. The goal of the procedure is long-term pain relief and restoration of function. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746-L749)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

documentation: Primary and secondary tumors of the proximal femur (Evidence: pg no: 24, L837)
Hip fracture or complications including malunion, nonunion or failed prior fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L838)
Failed previous hip fracture fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L839)
Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) with unresponsive severe pain (Evidence: pg no: 24, L840)
Revision of hip arthrodesis (Evidence: pg no: 24, L841)
Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L844-L845)
Limited range of motion, antalgic gait and disabling pain of at least 3 months' duration (Evidence: pg no: 24, L846)
Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)
Failure of at least 3 months of non-surgical conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 24, L848-L849)
Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 24, L850-L851)

exclusions: Indications for total hip arthroplasty other than those addressed in this guideline are considered not medically necessary (Evidence: pg no: 26, L937-L938)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, acetabular and proximal femoral prosthetic replacement (total hip arthroplasty), with or without autograft or allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L973-L974)

full_source.notes: All arthroplasty and acetabuloplasty/resection arthroplasty procedures are inclusive of synovectomy, removal of osteophytes, removal of loose bodies, manipulation of the hip, and release or repair of structures to gain entrance to the hip joint. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L749-L751)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also referred to as total hip replacement (THR), involves removal of the femoral head and acetabulum and placement of a prosthesis anchored to the bone. The goal of the procedure is long-term pain relief and restoration of function. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746-L749)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

documentation: Primary and secondary tumors of the proximal femur (Evidence: pg no: 24, L837)
Hip fracture or complications including malunion, nonunion or failed prior fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L838)

Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) with unresponsive severe pain (Evidence: pg no: 24, L840)
Revision of hip arthrodesis (Evidence: pg no: 24, L841)
Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L844-L845)
Limited range of motion, antalgic gait and disabling pain of at least 3 months' duration (Evidence: pg no: 24, L846)
Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)

Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 24, L850-L851)

full_source.description: Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also referred to as total hip replacement (THR), involves removal of the femoral head and acetabulum and placement of a prosthesis anchored to the bone. The goal of the procedure is long-term pain relief and restoration of function. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746-L749)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

full_source.notes: All arthroplasty and acetabuloplasty/resection arthroplasty procedures are inclusive of synovectomy, removal of osteophytes, removal of loose bodies, manipulation of the hip, and release or repair of structures to gain entrance to the hip joint. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L749-L751)

full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. This procedure is typically utilized when there is concomitant rotator cuff disease. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178-L180)

original_chart:
OPERATIVE REPORT

Patient Name: Marcus Allen
MRN: 563298741
Date of Service: August 19, 2025
Surgeon: Dr. Priya Desai, MD

PROCEDURES PERFORMED:
1. Arthroscopic anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction, right knee
2. Arthroscopic partial medial meniscectomy, right knee

INDICATIONS:
28-year-old male recreational basketball player with pivot injury and persistent instability despite bracing and therapy.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Complete ACL tear, right knee
2. Complex medial meniscus tear, right knee

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Same as above.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
Under general anesthesia the right knee was prepped and draped. Diagnostic arthroscopy confirmed ACL insufficiency and peripheral medial meniscus tear. Torn meniscal fragments were trimmed to a stable rim. Tunnels were created in the tibia and femur following standard guide technique. Graft was passed and secured with interference screws. Final arthroscopic inspection demonstrated restored tension with negative pivot shift on testing.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal.
COMPLICATIONS: None.
DRAINS: None.

IMPLANTS:
Femoral and tibial interference screws placed. Specific graft type not documented in operative record.

POSTOPERATIVE PLAN:
Brace locked in extension. Standard ACL protocol to begin with supervised therapy. Weight-bearing status to be advanced per rehabilitation milestones.
